title: Automatic Thoughts: What’s Growing in the Garden of Your Mind?
description: This article introduces the idea of “automatic thoughts” in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). We use the image of an apple tree to explain the hierarchy of beliefs behind our quick emotional reactions, and show how life experience shapes our first thoughts and feelings.

texts: From the previous chapter, we already know that our thoughts affect our emotions and physical reactions.
Now, building on the basics, let’s turn to what we’ll work with in practice.
We thought about how best to illustrate the hierarchy of beliefs in CBT and concluded that a tree is the clearest image.
Picture an apple tree in front of you. It represents your mind. On its branches hang fruits—some bright and ripe, others bruised or spoiled.
The fruits on this tree are your thoughts.
In CBT, these thoughts are called “automatic” because they appear quickly, almost imperceptibly, and without conscious effort.
There are so many of them—and they’re so fleeting—that we often don’t even notice them appear.

quote.text: It isn’t events themselves but our judgments about them that make us happy or unhappy.
quote.author: Epictetus

texts: Let’s try a thought experiment.
Imagine you’re sitting in a movie theater, waiting for the film to start.
Suddenly, a woman in the row ahead jumps up and slaps the man next to her.
It’s a sharp, emotionally charged situation. Imagine what automatic thoughts might flare up for you—and what feelings you’d experience.
We can’t know your personal history or predict your exact reaction.
So let’s imagine two people sitting beside you.
On your left is a woman in her forties who has experienced domestic violence in the past. Here’s what her internal reaction might look like:
On your right is a young man who has recently gone through a long, difficult divorce.
As you can see, the same event triggers very different emotions in different people, because each of us views the world through the lens of our own experience.
These fast, involuntary reactions are what we call automatic thoughts.
stepper_1: Poor thing—she’ll probably face consequences at home for this.
stepper_2: What a shameless person! Couldn’t she wait until they were home instead of making a scene in public?

test.question: Automatic thoughts are:
answers: Fragmentary and numerous; they arise involuntarily

texts: Why, then, do different people think differently in the very same situation?
Does that mean that whenever something unpleasant happens, we’re doomed to a vicious cycle of thoughts and emotions that leads to depression?
Not at all.
Although everyone has automatic thoughts, they don’t always cause psychological difficulties.
The thoughts that arise are linked to deeper beliefs and internal assumptions.
Just as fruits don’t exist apart from the branches, trunk, and roots of a tree, our automatic thoughts rest on intermediate and core beliefs.
